ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?

I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned skills in analyzing and reading Japanese historical documents and the context behind them. It was like learning a different language almost.

I learned to read srbun, known as the Japanese epistolary style, which was the most common form of writing in early modern documents. I also developed skills in reading kuzushiji, a type of cursive, although this was not the main goal of the class. The instructor also did a wonderful job of teaching specific aspects of early modern Japanese society through the documents, especially the social life of Kyoto and its neighborhoods.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was a great introduction to reading Japanese historical documents. There was so much support for questions. I really liked that I wasn't afraid of not knowing things or asking questions which I typically face in other Yale classes. I also appreciated how the course gradually got more difficult, it flowed very well.

One strength of this course was that on top of the main instructor, there was a co-instructor who is an expert in Japanese paleography and helped clarify many things, and the Japan Studies librarian also attended each session and contributed to students' understanding of the material and access to resources on it.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The instructor only used material in the course that could be accessed online or viewed as PDFs, which worked well for the remote nature of the course.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course if you are interested in Japanese history and want to continue with language practice. You don't need to be an expert in the Japanese language to take this class. In addition to learning how to read sorobun, you also get a detailed history with personal accounts. There is also an opportunity to pursue your own research interests with the final project. It was a small class and there was so much support.

Certainly! The skills taught in this class are very specific but also incredibly valuable for anyone doing research on Japan from a historical perspective. Prof. Botsman also has a very engaging and animated attitude toward the material, which made the learn all the more affective.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: One virtual "visit" to the Beinecke library. We examined a digitized scrolled held by the Beinecke.
